articles.headline: Billionaire Backs a Gas-Electric Hybrid Car to Be Built in Russia
articles.snippet: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who bought the New Jersey Nets basketball team, introduced another pet project Monday: a Russian-designed hybrid electric car.
articles.abstract: Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who bought the New Jersey Nets basketball team, introduced another pet project Monday: a Russian-designed hybrid electric car.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW  Mikhail D. Prokhorov, the Russian billionaire who owns the New Jersey Nets basketball team, rolled out another pet project on Monday: Russia’s first gas-electric hybrid car.

articles.headline: Fed’s Contrarian Has a Wary Eye on the Past
articles.snippet: Thomas M. Hoenig fears that the Fed’s efforts to move the recovery along quickly will create the conditions for repeating past mistakes, like spurring inflation.
articles.abstract: Thomas M. Hoenig fears that the Fed’s efforts to move the recovery along quickly will create the conditions for repeating past mistakes, like spurring inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: KANSAS CITY, Mo.  All year, Thomas M. Hoenig has been saying no.

articles.headline: Telecom Scandal Plunges India Into Political Crisis
articles.snippet: Allegations of bribery, abuse of power and privatization of public wealth have sent the Congress Party into a tailspin.
articles.abstract: Allegations of bribery, abuse of power and privatization of public wealth have sent the Congress Party into a tailspin.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI  Tycoons with friends in high places. Public tenders conducted by irregular rules. Tens of billions of dollars in potential losses for the national treasury. Allegations of government ministers on the take, and of a respected prime minister too aloof to notice.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Heather Timmons

articles.headline: Killings of Afghan Relief Workers Stir Debate
articles.snippet: Aid groups wonder if the American military strategy in Afghanistan is putting their workers at risk.
articles.abstract: Aid groups wonder if the American military strategy in Afghanistan is putting their workers at risk.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  At least 100 relief workers in Afghanistan have been killed so far this year, far more than in any previous year, prompting a debate within humanitarian organizations about whether American military strategy is putting them and the Afghans they serve at unnecessary risk.

articles.headline: Tax Breaks Bring Hope for Hiring
articles.snippet: The cuts in the Obama administration’s plan that are intended for businesses may prompt manufacturers to spend on hiring and capital improvements.
articles.abstract: The cuts in the Obama administration’s plan that are intended for businesses may prompt manufacturers to spend on hiring and capital improvements.
articles.lead_paragraph: To many manufacturing companies, the tax cut proposal now being considered in Washington may be just enough to spur additional spending and hiring.

articles.headline: Piracy Fight Shuts Down Music Blogs
articles.snippet: Popular music blogs shut down by the government in a Thanksgiving weekend crackdown on online piracy often operate with the tacit aid and approval of major labels.
articles.abstract: Popular music blogs shut down by the government in a Thanksgiving weekend crackdown on online piracy often operate with the tacit aid and approval of major labels.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thanksgiving Day had barely begun when Kevin Hofman’s BlackBerry buzzed. It was one of the technical operators of OnSmash.com, Mr. Hofman’s popular hip-hop blog, telling him that the site had gone mysteriously blank just after midnight.

articles.headline: Strong American Voice in Diplomacy and Crisis
articles.snippet: Mr. Holbrooke made a career that started with Vietnam, had a highlight with Bosnia and ended in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.abstract: Mr. Holbrooke made a career that started with Vietnam, had a highlight with Bosnia and ended in Afghanistan and Pakistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Richard C. Holbrooke, the Obama administration’s special representative for Afghanistan and Pakistan since 2009 and a diplomatic troubleshooter who worked for every Democratic president since the late 1960s and oversaw the negotiations that ended the war in Bosnia, died Monday evening in Washington. He was 69 and lived in Manhattan.

articles.headline: The Room Is Booked, Until the Hotel Says It Isn’t
articles.snippet: A number of people with reservations at the Waldorf-Astoria were turned away over Thanksgiving when the Saudi king and his contingent needed rooms.
articles.abstract: A number of people with reservations at the Waldorf-Astoria were turned away over Thanksgiving when the Saudi king and his contingent needed rooms.
articles.lead_paragraph: When is a confirmed hotel reservation not confirmed? When the hotel has sold your room to someone else, as Linda and Michael Morgan learned over the Thanksgiving holiday.
